Situation1: The passenger is heading to a casual meeting with plenty of time
Situation2: They have been scheduled to chant a portion during the service.
Story: I glanced at the dashboard clock as I pulled up to the curb, my yarmulke tucked in my pocket, hidden beneath my cap. The passenger slid into the back seat, chatting about his meeting, mentioning he had more than enough time. I smiled, nodding, but my mind was elsewhere. Tonight was my turn to chant at synagogue, a responsibility I’d accepted weeks ago. The service would start in less than an hour, and I’d planned my shift so I could leave early. But now, with this ride, I was caught. As a taxi driver, I’m expected to get my passenger to his destination safely and on time, no matter how relaxed his schedule. As a Jew, I’m expected to be present, to honor my commitment to the community and to God. My hands tightened on the wheel. If I cut the ride short or rushed, I’d be failing my duty as a driver. If I stayed too long, I’d miss my place at the bimah. The city lights blurred as I wrestled with the weight of both worlds, unsure which path to follow.
